description:
A hidden, life-restoring gem. (No Dreamforce zombies, I was careful to cover my tracks.) 

I'm in love with their lattes, clever and low-key staff, and an ever excellent soundtrack going. Thank goodness their pain au chocolate are not regularly available.
author: Mutant O.

description: Fantastic coffee around the corner from the office. So good the boss always sends me down when he's in town.
author: Gretchen J.

description:
So cool that we have to walk through a back alley to get here. I tried a Macau Iced Coffee this morning - super sweet, reminiscent of Vietnamese iced coffee, but it was just what I needed after a long night of telling jokes and public transportation back home.

Kind of pricey but on par with everything else around this area. 

CASH ONLY!
author: Aivy C.

description: $5 minimum on credit cards, even tho my $4.75 coffee easily became $5 with tax and a tip. Pretty mediocre, expensive coffee.
author: Susan I.

description:
This is some of the best coffee around and the people who work there are really nice.  I do wish they took cards but there are ATMs nearby so it's really not that big of an issue.

The Macau iced coffee and iced tea are both pretty tasty.
author: Jason F.

description: Best cappuccino in the area!! I love this place, so much better than Starbucks!! The place is a little challenging to find but it's so worth the efforts!
author: Rachida I.

description:
Special Xtra is both. See what I did there? 

Seriously tho, I like this little joint a lot. It's a coffee cart stuffed inside the front door of a bar/restaurant on an alleyway down in SOMA. The friendly baristas serve up a short menu of espresso drinks made with Blue Bottle coffee. The espresso is really tasty. But what I come here for is the cold brew. Special Xtra makes a mean cold brew, and they put chicory in the coffee, which adds a nice extra flavor to embolden the smoothness inherent in cold brew.  Grab a cold brew, add some half n' half, and you have a little refreshing kickstart for your day. 

The only complaint? Cold drinks in paper cups. If they had plastic I'd be as snug as a bug in a rug with the whole shebang. 

Oh yeah, it's cash only. So don't forget your duckets.
author: Don B.

description:
This would be a five star review if not for the cash only situation.  PLEASE, PLEASE start taking credit cards.  Just get an iPad and Square.  I KNOW there's a Chase ATM in spitting distance, but I really don't like handling cash and carrying change around and all of that - plus I want my credit card points.  I also think the operation here would run more smoothly if they took credit cards - right now, I feel as though the two people making coffee spend an overly long time taking money, making change, etc.  Seriously, PLEASE.  I would be here every day if you did...

Anyway, the coffee.  They use Blue Bottle, so you know it's going to be good.  Their Au Lait is on point.  It's really, really yummy.  It has real depth, and I'm happy to see them using Clover milk.  Also, I'm glad they have agave sweetener. I gave up the artificial stuff years ago and I just feel like this is easier than sugar granules.

They also have AWESOME pastries.  Every one I've had is terrific.  The morning bun is fantastic (I feel like it has to be Tartine, but I don't know), the chocolate chip cookies are amazing, and then all the other cookies like the coconut chocolate chip and the chocolate chip / nut / popcorn crazy one are also great.  They occasionally have cheddar scones or something like that which look awesome and I definitely need to try in the near future.  I very much appreciate that they have food all day, unlike let's say Red Door Coffee...

I just think this place is the bees knees.  It's cool and tucked away and, most importantly, very high quality / delicious.  Just PLEASE stop this cash-only nonsense...it makes your business look less legit and it's really annoying to me.
author: Tay H.

description:
I tried Special Xtra for the convenience of having Blue Bottle coffee as an option.  It beats walking to the Ferry Building in the morning and their prices are about the same.  This hidden coffee cart isn't really a secret anymore as I see that there are plenty of regulars that the baristas know their usual orders.  Since they do pour overs for coffee and espresso drinks with steamed milk, it does take a while if there's a line of three to four people.  

Probably will come back here based on the line and people waiting in front.  Otherwise, I'll move on and go to Proper Food for a quick decent cup o joe.
author: Ben H L.

description:
My favorite latte in financial district! A good location for anyone downtown, and near public seating so you can sit and enjoy a pastry. 

Oh, they are cash only, so make sure and hit up the ATM first! :)
author: D M.

description:
Coffee by day, bar by night.

This has to be my new favorite coffee shop. I'm tired of the same ol' plain ol' here in SF (you know, the Peet's, Starbucks, Coffee Bean blablabla). Had lunch with a friend then asked him where I should get coffee. He described it as, "Go down those stairs and into an alley and keep walking" because he couldn't remember the name of it.

Anyways, he wanted coffee too, so he showed me where it was. We get to Special Xtra, wait in the short 5 person line ahead of us (apparently this place gets crowded so we were in luck!) which gave me a few minutes to decide what I wanted. 

I was even more excited that they serve Blue Bottle, one of my SF favs! Score. 

Ordered a latte, friend got a drip and we parted ways. 

Cute, unique, and comfy. I'll be back!
author: Shereen A.

description: Cool concept and great coffee! These guys figured they can rent out spaces that are vacant during the day and serve quality coffee in busy downtown without paying crazy rent. Coffee is great and price is reasonable.
author: Joseph L.

description:
I used to really really like this place and have recommended this cafe to several friends, but after my experience I'm reluctant to go back.

I didn't mind that they sell iced coffee in a paper cup and take cash only because I really like their coffee and delicious cookies, and so I always tip them too.

However, when I tried to take a picture of the cafe from far away (so I can show my friends my favorite hole in the wall coffee shop), the guy working (probably the owner) called out "ma'am" a few times. I didn't think he was talking to me at first because I just put my order in and I was a little too far away to hear, but people standing in front of the counter started looking back at me. I heard it the second time, and that's when I thought that maybe he's telling me that my coffee was ready to pick-up. Excited to grab my coffee, I see the guy shake his head and says "ma'am, do not take my picture" in front of everyone. I was a little taken aback because I told him smiling that I was only trying to take a picture of the coffee shop.. and all he replied was "I know" and not in a good way. It was uncomfortable for everyone around us. The lady (barista) next to him then hands me my drink... and before leaving the store I say "thank you" but I didn't get a thank you back from him. Not sure what his problem is....
author: Joyce C.

description:
Awesome coffee; a hidden gem in an unexpected location (hole in the wall in the alley on Minna St), just steps from my office.  Can't go wrong with anything you order here - they serve Blue Bottle Coffee, and everything I've tried has been delicious. 

My husband and I have been here many times, and will continue to be repeat customers.  My husband typically orders their slow drip coffee or a cappuccino.  I usually order their americano when I want something to warm me up, or their New Orleans iced coffee on warm SF afternoons (so good!).  

I also love that this place is hidden away from the mainstream traffic; however, while hidden away, there is always a crowd of people waiting for their coffee, so clearly they don't need a huge display/advertisement to get business.  Their coffee speaks for itself!

They also offer some delicious looking baked goods, that seriously tempt me each time I go to order.  One of these times I'm going to have to indulge in one of those awesome looking chocolate chip cookies...
author: Rachael S.

description:
CASH ONLY

There's nothing like a day in the office during tax season. 14 hour work day staring at tax returns on a computer screen? A rest break in SF's beautiful March weather is much needed. 

My incharge pulls me off my computer and we go for a walk. He wants to be outside, he wants blue bottle coffee. We venture into the sunlight, on this warm day. We head down second street and turn left onto Minna. This place is just hidden behind the Deloitte building.

It's a literal hole in the wall. Most prices are 3.25-3.75, except the semi sweet mocha, which is 4.25. Even at 3pm, there is a small line!

Good coffee at this hidden location.

*no, I don't work at deloitte.
author: Kaje Y.

description:
My friend recommended me here, because I'm a coffee drinker. That was a really great advice for the stranger.
I ordered soy latte. It was very nice, creamy and the taste of milk was soft and sweet.
Unfortunately their Peanut butter cookies, that my friend's favorite, was out of stock at that time. The staff told said that he loves it too. I have to try it again soon!
author: Rika N.

description:
After falling for Special Xtra 2, I wanted to check out the original located just a few blocks up Minna St.
Like Special Xtra 2, it's a cash-only, friendly place that serves Blue Bottle.
Unlike Special Xtra 2, it's more of a hole-in-wall. You order from the sidewalk. Seating is outside at the plaza next door, but it's also uncomfortably close to the construction, so I would plan to drink the coffee elsewhere.
If you're up for walking an extra three blocks for your coffee, Special Xtra 2 has a nice little indoor seating area.
One super minor complaint is that I got an iced coffee in a paper cup, which tend to get soggy and gross.
author: Jessica S.

description: Super special fancy coffee spot. Latte time!
author: Dejana B.

description:
When I come here, I feel like I should be riding a chartreuse Vespa, talking like Vincent Price, and wearing a herring-bone sportscoat with a peach ascot to match the rose in my cheeks. Otherwise I don't feel worthy of the Blue Bottle coffee served in this little stand hidden on Minna away from most of the masses. The only reason I knew it was here was a colleague who pooh-poohed my suggestion we go to Peet's. Quel embarrassment. Well, you could have knocked me over with a Mr. Coffee paper filter because I deify Blue Bottle at the altar of rarefied caffeine. 

There's a manageable list of premium coffee drinks to choose from, and my $3.50 Cafe Latte was so smooth I felt like someone shaved my tongue with a velvet roller. They also serve various designer cookies from Goody Goodie Cream & Sugar if you are so inclined. I have yet to try them myself. The closest seating available is on the benches at the mini-plaza at 555 Mission where you can either look at the multi-colored, multi-men metal sculpture or the devastation that will someday become the Transbay Transit Center. There's definitely a crowd that gathers throughout the day, so don't be too surprised if you have to wait.

COFFEE - 4 stars...one smooth cup of java
AMBIANCE - 3 stars...a hidden kiosk and nothing more
SERVICE - 3 stars...no complaints from me
TOTAL - 4 stars...don't touch my Vespa
author: Ed U.

description:
A secret gem on Minna St. if you're looking for a Blue Bottle caffeine boost! Open on weekdays from 7:30 AM - 4:00 PM PT- cash only.
The Macau Iced Coffee and the [non-fat] Mocha are my favorites- delicious. The service here is pretty straight forward and you get what you ask for. There is usually a line so be prepared for that.
author: Grace L.

description: A small hole in the wall with excellent coffee and nice staff. I gave it 4 stars only because it is cash only- 5 stars if they accepted cards.
author: Adam B.

description: This is a great little hidden gem of a spot to get your caffeine on. My macchiato was spot on. Cash only, third wave fosho. This place rocks.
author: Andrew K.

description: Awesome blue bottle coffee close to work. This is a great little stand which opens early and has great coffee.
author: Jonah K.

description: This place consistently pours some of the best espresso in the city.  Having to drink it in an alley next to the Transbay construction is just part of the charm.
author: Dan H.

description:
Great concept, friendly service.  I love single drip coffee, and this roaster was excellent.  The two young women behind the counter were friendly, and fast.  

Highly recommended, worth the walk.
author: Bruce S.

description: I tracked down Special Xtra after seeing their sign for Macau iced coffee during my lunchtime walks. It was just ok - what seemed like a shot of espresso diluted with a cup of milk, plus what appeared to be a drizzle of simple syrup (not condensed milk as some reviewers have written - there wasn't the telltale white layer settled on the bottom of the cup).  Nothing special. My hunt for a decent Vietnamese iced coffee in the downtown area continues (used to be Curbside Coffee, but they closed).
author: Bella L.

description:
Soon as i walked up & saw the Blue Bottle Coffee sign, I knew this was going to be another one of "those" experiences.....and I was right

Advised they only have a double-shot filter, my choice was a double or a quad-shot & in a 12 oz cup, which was the largest they offered, 4-shots may have a bit too much.....so double it was.  $3.50

Soon as I'm handed the cup I can already tell it's still cold which is my constant gripe w/ places that serve Blue Bottle.  Why does BB have a vendetta against hot coffee drinks?!

By the time I walked 1 block to the office, it was completely frigid.  Had to heat it up in the microwave to make it even drinkable

The ratio of coffee to milk was decent & they serve yummy Clover milk which is always creamier than your average milk but it's the temperature I couldn't tolerate

Sorry guys, but I've had better.......
author: Adrienne G.

description: Special Xtra is now using beans from Cento Coffee, instead of Blue Bottle. Happily, the New Orleans iced coffee and Macu drinks are still on the menu. Quick, easy, and yum!
author: Johanna S.

description:
Great coffee and iced coffee combined with some of the nicest staff I've ever met.  It's cash only so bring some dollars, but process are reasonable and if they know you they'll let you pay next time if you forget by chance.

Good music and a nice vibe complete the chill atmosphere.  Strongly recommend the iced coffees and poor overs.
author: Patrick P.

description:
It's kinda hard to convince someone who is new to the area to go to Special Xtra, since it's located in the alleyway with very little human traffic. If you go during the day, with a group of people, and got sick of the overpriced and not awakening coffee from your famous coffee chains, then you should come here and try some Blue Bottle Coffee. 

This place is cash only, and their drinks fall into the $3-5 range. My group usually get the Macau Iced Coffee, it's sweet and very milky in taste to mask the strong espresso. I prefer the New Orleans Iced Coffee since I don't have a habit of adding sugar to my coffee. On cold days, I like to order their Soy Lattes, it's so smooth and slightly bitter from the coffee taste. 

If you are very sensitive to caffeine, I wouldn't recommend you to buy your coffee here past 3pm.
author: Connie C.

description:
Another cute hole-in-the-wall cafe that is literally just an open space with a coffee machine in it. Serving up Blue Bottle coffee and sweets with a smile, this friendly little spot churns out good coffee, fast. 

Cash only, so bring your change.
author: Mel P.

description: I had coffee twice. First time was great. Second time was bad; coffee tested like water and NO it's not the roast type. I drink black coffee without sugar and I can easily tell good & bad coffee. I felt like the guy made two coffee without changing the coffee powder on the second one. I don't think Blue Bottle is that bad and this would not pass their standard at all.
author: Mike N.

description:
Very similar to Cento in SoMa. This place is a hole in a wall (literally in this case though quite presentable). It is tucked away in an alleyway which makes it a real gem of a find. 

The coffee is from Blue Bottle. They make a good cappuccino. This is a great place for a coffee break but don't expect to be able to sit down -- standing room on the sidewalk only.
author: Victor W.

description:
When you're fighting the coffee "man" you have surprisingly few options in downtown San Francisco. 

If its a nice day (and here in SF it usually is) I'd recommend checking out Special Xtra. The mocha is decidedly less good but all of their other coffees are well made. In particular I recommend the Macau (for that warm afternoon when you feel like splurging a little) for a rich, sweet, icy beverage comprised of milk, simple syrup and espresso over ice. 

Be warned - cash only!
author: Stephanie T.

description:
Little. Tiny. Different.

Anyone remember that commercial? Anyways that about sums up Special Xtra. Hiding out in Harlot's smoking cage during the day, you'll find chill folks serving some decent espresso. If you go early enough in the afternoon you can catch the sun, assuming there is any...
author: Jeremy S.

description:
Best coffee and coffee people in the neighborhood.

Love the prosciutto / havarti croissants too!

on a hot day, go for the New Orleans iced coffee or a citrus green tea. 

perhaps best of all, there is a lovely court yard just down the way where you can relax, sip your espresso, then return the cup when you are done.
author: Matthew D.

description: Love Blue Bottle Coffe, and love that it's a tiny hole in the wall in an alley behind some corporate-ish buildings.  The regular black coffee is deep and rich, which pales in comparison to some of the other coffees that are in the area.  They have delicious looking pastries in the window too!  The line was pretty long for a Friday at 10am, but I guess it makes sense when you taste the coffee.  Pretty sure they're cash only, so please come prepared!
author: Lisa I.

description: This is the first time I have ever been actually impressed with an iced green tea. There may have been some lemon and ginger flavoring, not sure what exactly made it taste so good.
author: Geoffrey B.

description: Quite good, especially considering what all else is available in the area. Cash only, but there is a Chase ATM within spitting distance of their coffee stand. I went here somewhat regularly until the one barista who I felt was the nicest and actually made the best coffee left to work full-time elsewhere.
author: Patricia D.

description: So I had a coffee from the back of a restaurant under a bridge with construction going on and dust was all over the place ending up in my coffee? I had to go study in the library after that and had to ask twice for a cover that would fit my cup and take a straw, feeling like I was ripping off ecology or something. The cover did not work well and I ended up spilling coffee here and there on my papers. The coffee was ok but so is the coffee from my espresso machine.
author: Selene N.

description:
What a hole in a wall?!?! Blue Bottle Coffee - Yumm. A very cool and afst serving spot. What a SF experience?!?

Love it!
author: Jenna F.

description: This cash only coffee kiosk serves one of the best hot chocolates in SoMa. Theirs is semi-sweet and satisfying and small enough to avoid being sinful. Occasionally I also partake in their peanut butter cookie, which is soft, chewy and perfectly peanutty.
author: Miriam W.

description:
A sweet kiosk, at which you can get your Blue Bottle fix in the financial district.

Right beside Harlot and wedged in a cute little partitioned area on Minna street - Special Xtra serves up Blue Bottle specialty coffee drinks, as well as Goody Goodie Cream & Sugar chocolate chip cookies.

For an ornate milk froth topped cup of caffeine lined goodness  - get your special xtra - at Special xtra.

Trust.
author: Jessica T.

description:
They have free coffee at my office. Dun matter.
There are thousands of coffee shops in the area. Dun matter. 
They have great K-cup flavors for my home brewing machine. Dun matter.

I'm still going to go out of my way to get blue bottle coffee from this place. Problem?
author: Nick A.

description:
This is truly one of those hidden gems surrounded by tons of franchised coffee shops. When I say hidden, it is actually a bit hard to find lol. They are located in the alley right behind salt house. 

I'm not a big fan of coffee but they offer Blue Bottle Drip coffee and a few different types of tea. I got the rose tea last time and it was quite refreshing as it was served cold.

They also offer a few different pastries and the staff has always been very friendly and quick.

Food Highlight: Can't go wrong with Blue Bottle and going to try all their teas before updating this review
author: Rich L.

description: After a filling dim sum lunch, walked around the Financial District and stumbled across this great coffee shop (next to the nightclub Harlot). Cappuccino was extra tasty and the coffee was extra flavorful. Cash only, just for reference.
author: David G.

description: Been coming here for several years now but more recently have been frequenting this tiny coffee shop more often because it's my coworkers' favorite. I enjoy the short walk to here from the office and when we get here, we're always greeted by a smile by the lovely girl behind the counter. They serve only Blue Bottle so you know it's quality coffee. I don't think you can go wrong with your order. Our go to is the Macau, this will help you through your afternoons at work. Cash only.
author: Cindy W.

description:
Blue Bottle: the best coffee preparation in the city.

You like coffee?  You really like coffee?  You'll love Blue Bottle.  

Better than any chain.  Makes Petes & Starbucks look novice.
author: Stephanie F.

description:
I love this place. Not only do they serve Blue Bottle Coffee, they do it nicely. If you go there more than once, they will know your face, soon after, your name. And they will know your order. 

And oddly, no one cares that they have to step over a homeless guy in order to get their coffee. 

It's just nice to have a place that has great service, great coffee and is generally just a pleasure to go to.
author: Mariko F.

description:
I was surprised to find this place is not called "Alley Coffee" since that it what I insist upon calling it. And that's not just some clever nomenclature, either. It's wholly descriptive of the experience of going to Special Xtra. This coffee-pocket is no wider than a Toyota Previa is long, and no matter when you go you'll encounter a queue of uncaffenated dudes and dudes and dudettes loitering for a cup.

Serving Blue Bottle Coffee, I've never been disappointed in their offerings. Coffee Alley serves espresso drinks and individual drip. The drip sometimes takes a while (2 minutes) so I'll get a cappuccino if I'm feeling impatient. They also have some mean iced coffee conconctions like "The Macau": Vietnamese style joe loaded with condensed milk. You'll probably get the 'betes if you drink these daily. Alleyside Coffee is also reliable for gooey nommable cookies

I said "nommable." I should cease reviewing immediately.

Obligatory Title Pun: ALLEY oop!

Menu Readability: Take note of the clever 3D caricature of the staff made with Sharpie and coffee filters. I said take note!

Need to mention: They are closed by 4pm daily. And they are cash only.

What this place teaches me about myself: Hot fluids? Gooey treats? Alleyways?
author: Vivek S.

description:
Macau Ice Coffee! - I actually had this before I tried the real Blue Bottle in the Ferry Building. I can say that maybe I even like this more because I've just gotten used to how great it taste. 

Definitely a "hole in the wall" that who works in those few blocks have heard of.  Once I discovered it, I definitely converted from Starbucks to here for the rest of my summer internship. The line is much faster than the Starbucks or Peets around the block, and the guys/gals will start knowing you by name.  

It was kinda hard to find the place using Google Maps/Yelp the first time. This place is behind the Deloitte building.  It's the driveway behind the building facing the construction site.
author: Alan Z.

description:
I love love love this little coffee shop!  I love it even more because it's located right behind my building.  

On the days I do go to this office, I make sure I get at least 1 cup of goodness from this place.  At least 1, I think I once had 3 in a day.  They use Blue Bottle Coffee beans for their coffees.  I started off ordering the Drip, which is hand dripped by the super friendly and interesting baristas.  The drip is so smooth, so genuinely and down-to-earthly good.  Then I became a soy latte fan.  SOOO good.  SO SO SO good.  The drip might be a bit too strong for those non-lovers, but their soy latte... YUMMM.  The organic soy milk they use adds a lightly sweet taste to the coffee (so no need for sugar), and helps tone down the bitterness of the coffee, enhancing the coffee aroma.
author: Emily W.

description:
I'm digging what these Lambretta boys are doing. I spied a Lambretta crossing Cyril Magnin the other day, and thought, you could definitely fit the Special Xtra coffee stand on the back of that thing. 

I've read about their house iced coffee over at Cento, and this Special Xtra stand has its own house iced recipe: The Macau -- whoever Uncle Kirk is whom is created with the concoction... he's a wise chap to dump a macchiato over ice, and adding more whole milk. They're sourcing Blue Bottle... Blue Bottle should come take note of how they're pulling their shots... as I've started migrating away from the Mint & over here instead. 

The lambrettistas are mighty kind & accommodating. When my adventure to find out what the song over the speakers was... my Shazaam sputtered out (shockah!), chap pulled a ristretto while finding the song name & artist. 

Cash only, Chase cash hole-in-the-wall 20 yards from the stand. When you arrive there will be a line. When you leave there will be a line. When you move through your cup of coffee you'll be thinking about getting right back in line for more.
author: Jon A.

description:
I can only comment on the Iced Macau as it is the only thing I ever get here. It's expensive compared to chain coffee such as Starbucks. They put some milk and I believe a bit of sweetener in the iced Macau. 

What special about it?

It's got that smoothness to it that tells you it's gonna be a good cup of coffee.
author: R H.

description: I love the whole idea of the roll-up door in the alley, and I also love their muddy Americanos.
author: Robert M.

description:
Great little spot for that much needed coffee break during the work day. 

Usually a short line that goes quickly. Waiting for your coffee will take a little more time... but the wait is worth it for the delightful warm beverage.

They serve Blue Bottle - cash only.
author: Shannon H.

description:
Blue Bottle coffee in a tucked away alley location is hecka cool by me.  You gotta love it anytime another place serving truly superior coffee opens up.  All the better when it's between your parking lot and the office.  

These folks are kind and make an incredible latte.  The drip I had didn't blow me away, it was the Three Africas blend that day.  But no stars deducted, because the lattes are that magnificent.  

The only thing bad about Special Xtra is the long line during that morning rush hour.  So I go if I have a minute to slip away for a morning or afternoon break, that's when I hit 'em up.  

I'm not going to complain about the homeless guys, they're the same ones who've been part of my commute for years now.  Sad question is, where will they go when the mega-tower begins construction?  Life is filled with intractable questions.  Thank gawd for xtra special coffee.
author: Ted R.

description:
They're fast.  They're right behind my building.  They're not disgusting Peet's acidic coffee.  What more can you ask for.  Staff is really nice too.

Macau Iced Coffee - really delicious sweetened flavored ice coffee!  

Soy Latte - I love when baristas know how to make lattes with the creamy foam on top.  That's THE BEST PART!!!!! They also use some kind of organic soy milk that's not kirkland brand.  Horray because kirkland brand sucks and always curdles.
author: Anna T.

description:
Coffee is good but the "rules" ridiculous.   They won't "do" an espresso or macchiato in a to-go cup.  Funny because there is no place to sit or stand near this kiosk. Okay you can stand but it is next to a construction site. Not one chair or even a counter for your coffee. 

To allow someone get a cappuccino to-go but not a macchiato is darn right STUPID! Please explain... if the answer is you do not want to "ruin" the coffee... well you sell ice coffee. You will ruin coffee by putting ice and other processed flavors in them but won't put a straight shot in a paper cup.  Brilliant!

I appreciate a great coffee and would not mind having my coffee there but the environmental/atmosphere is horrible around this kiosk. Not sure hipster Ed, the one who gave me the stink-eye when I asked for my drink to be in a to-go cup, but any chance you notice that the customers are the ones standing outside getting sprayed with hydraulic fluid and other construction debris while waiting for our coffee.  why would anyone want to stand around this kiosk is beyond me.   Everything should be in to-go cup. Good luck.
author: Aus B.

description:
I was on my way to peet's coffee when I noticed the Special Xtra sign. I first thought it was a new type of sporting goods store but then I noticed the Blue Bottle icon. I was sold! I looked down the street for this alleged coffee place and saw nothing but a empty road, parking lot, and a homeless person. Despite seeing nothing there but being so sick of peet's coffee I started towards the emptiness. 

When I turned the corner, I was happy to find the tiny whole in the wall. Barely a counter, Special Xtra and it's goodness was there-- random cookies, menu sign, and ipod. Two girls were hanging out behind the counter. They were super sweet and got on my order right away. My soy latte wasn't as hot as I'd like it to have been but I'm definitely going to go back still.  It's only an empty lot away from work!
author: Veronica L.

description: Sometimes I feel like San Franciscans are obsessed with being in the know, even when it comes to their coffee breaks. But I have to admit that this part-time San Franciscan was pretty impressed to see this somewhat hidden little coffee kiosk in the Financial District, where caffeine starved office dwellers migrate at all hours of the workday to get their Blue Bottle fill. I highly enjoyed my beautiful espresso and the friendly demeanor of the two guys behind the counter. Make sure you contribute to their tip jar/earplug fund, as they're directly across from some major construction and I worry for their eardrums facing those loud jackhammers!
author: Christina P.

description:
This place is a hidden, delicious, crafted gem. It does require some patience, which is waiting in line to place your drink, but that is how most, if not all kiosks that serve Blue Bottle Coffee is. 

THIS PLACE SERVES REAL COFFEE. REAL ESPRESSO. The way it was originally meant to be consumed until places like Starbucks, Peets, and other major coffee shops slapped consumers with frappicinos, corn syrups, artificial sweeteners, and overbrewed coffee. 

Special Xtra is quality over quantity. Fresh. Real. Pure. 

In response to Yelper Aus B's review, I found it rather amusing, yet I felt the need to give him a diaper and a warm bottle. Seriously dude, if you want to have it your way, go to Burger King.
author: V V.

description:
SFGate had ranked Special Xtra's Macau iced coffee as the number 75th dish to try of 2011. Since I was in the Fidi, in a need of an afternoon pick-me-up, and curious of what a Macau iced coffee would taste like, I decided to give this a shot (no pun intended).

I thought Yelp was giving me the wrong address again, since I doubted there were businesses in this alley on the opposite of the street of the Transbay Terminal construction. But out of nowhere, there was a kiosk named Special Xtra. 

I ordered the Macau iced coffee and Angelica N is right: it tastes like coffee with leftover milk from cereal. It's not terribly sweet but it does taste like there's hint of syrup in it. The coffee is not especially strong, so it's a light espresso drink, nice and tasty. Macau iced coffee, off my to-try checklist!
author: Diana C.

description: The best coffee I've ever gotten out of an alley. Special Xtra has supplanted the Mint plaza Blue Bottle as my favorite coffee near the office, due almost entirely to the over-the-top sweet Macau iced coffee. The lines here are shorter than Blue Bottle, and the people working here seem less full of themselves too. Probably because they work in an alley.
author: Mark A.

description:
Dropped by here last Thursday. As others have pointed out, this place literally is a hole-in-the-wall. And, currently it is next to a very large hole in the ground.

Had to wait in line about 5 minutes to order and get my cappuccino. Glad I waited. It was worth it. Wish I'd asked which Blue Bottle beans the barista was pulling.
author: Darin T.

description:
This is my coffee go-to spot. I work about 2 blocks away, which is just enough to justify the excursion through Skid Row. No need to repeat all the raves here, so I'll just take the opportunity to make a jab at the nearby Specialities instead.

Specialities has gotten into the hand pour coffee craze. But get this: they charge $3.60 for a thoroughly mediocre cup while Special Xtra only charges $2.50 for a great cup. 

Oh, and Special Xtra is one of the few coffee places that knows how to make a proper macchiato.
author: Tristan N.

description: I was really excited to try this coffee spot today for their Macau iced coffee. It was a huge let down. Rude a$$ service and the Macau iced coffee was not good! All I could taste was just the soy milk. Maybe the people working there today was having a shitty morning! It was awful! I will def not be returning!!! Peace!
author: S C.

description:
Cash only - as cash is KING!!!

This place is great... a small little store front which has better coffee than other chain establishments. I got coffee after a hardy and heavy lunch to get me through the afternoon. 

I got the Iced Drip which was quick and they even added creme for me. There was a short line this time around, however sometimes in the mornings, the line can get quite long. The coffee did the trick to get me through the afternoon!

Def. a repeat purchase!
author: Vic F.

description:
I love this Blue Bottle location because it attracts both hipsters and corporate suits united by good coffee.  The individual drip coffee has a smokier, more roasted taste than national chain competitors.  The baked goods are AWESOME!  I had a Goody Goodie chocolate chip & coconut cookie.  Still had that runny chocolate chip effect so way fresher than baked goods from 'bucks or Peet's.

As for the wait, it actually wasn't that bad.  I've witness some Blue Bottle insanity at the Ferry Building, the staff being insanely slow and the customers being insane for waiting.  This location seems to have their shizz together because they know the corporate types don't have all day!
author: Adam B.

description:
Delicious iced green tea. They couple that works this place are full of energy and seem to have a blast at work. They often have a sweet radio station jammin' and will sing along to the songs while they brew your drink.

The only con is that they are located near a construction zone that still has a few years left of loud noises.
author: Jason M.

description:
I really want to love this place because of the yelp review but sorry to say it is just OK.

Since many yelpers had suggested the Macau's Iced Coffee, so I orderd that. It didn't have any "Wow" factor for me. I think it is over rated but also might be just this experience...who knows. I might give it a try again. So far it is just a normal coffee shop to me, nothing "Xtra"!
author: Vivi C.

description:
I've been on a coffee tour of my temporary home city, and like my friend Mark A., this is the best coffee I've ever had out of an alley. It's also the 2nd best coffee in the city. 

I'm not sure how a place that brews Blue Bottle coffee can make it better than Blue Bottle themselves, but Special Xtra does. Perhaps they leave out that extra dose of pretension... 

High five.
author: Allison S.

description:
Tucked in a little alley with never-ending construction rumbling across the street, this little Blue Bottle coffee gem is quite popular with nearby startup folks. Unfortunately, that translates to long lines sometimes. Compounding that issue is the 4pm closing time, which means at around 3:30pm, you might witness a mad rush of engineers.

This used to be my coffee of choice for some time, before my coworkers and I worked out a plan to go to MOMA instead. It wouldn't matter so much to me if I get drip coffee, but the MOMA Blue Bottle has affogato, while Special Xtra's "xtra special" is the Macau. I don't like my coffee strong, but I still view the Macau as a bit of a rip-off, considering it's mostly milk, with some espresso and syrup, cluttered up with ice.

Prices here are cheaper than MOMA, but the construction noise makes us shout to be heard, and there aren't any good spots to hang around near Special Xtra, except maybe the rather windy plaza with the funky statues.
author: Hannah H.

description:
YES they're Macau Iced Coffee is AWESOME. At first I thought it was simply the Hong Kong style iced coffee made with condensed milk, which I can get in Chinatown for half the price. However, they simply make it with sweetened milk and dense, dense Blue Bottle espresso. The coffee is so thick but smooth, it has this organically syrupy consistency heightened by the simple syrup--and hardly any trace of acidity. 

However, I'm knocking off a star because they've started to use these large plastic cups for their Macau iced coffee without tweaking the coffee to milk ratio. Usually (or, in my experience), they use smaller paper cups. With the large cups, the drink's watered down and doesn't have that thickness I crave. So disappointing- I hope this is just a case of low coffee supplies!!
author: Nicole L.

description:
This place you would never randomly find or stumble upon. My coworker brought me and for the entire walk there, I was wondering where were were going. Even though this place is essentially just a booth in an alley, it beats Starbucks or Peets for snacks. 

I had the chocolate chip coconut cookie, and it was incredible. They also had a great variety with chocolate chip kettle corn, chocolate chip peanut butter, chocolate chip etc. AMAZING. Very momofuku-esque. 

If you work in the area, this place is definitely worth the extra search. Not much variety but a great experience.
author: Chrissy H.

description: They have great coffee and are really nice!  I'd recommend trying the new orleans iced coffee.
author: Alex H.

description:
CASH ONLY.

Wavered between a 3-star to a 4-star due to price points and varying service.

Service is sometimes a hit or a miss depending on the mood of your servers. You can get really good service sometimes and another time, a grumpy server who make you wonder if you have done him/her something wrong.

I only order the soy latte here because it is really delicious. Their pastries too are really good. I love their muffins, that are filled with nuts/ fruit. Just delicious. Their cookies sometimes melt in the heat but are utterly sinful.

Alley smells, but what can you do about it?
author: SK L.

description: Thanks goodness for these satellite spots. Great blue bottle coffee. Lovely people serving it up.
author: Jennifer W.

description: So, I go to school across the street, have heard about this place for over a year now, and finally checked it out today.  I would have never found it if I didn't hear about it from Yelp/see the sign on the adjacent street from time to time.  Definitely going to be one of my new go-to spots for Blue Bottle before class time.
author: Mel G.

description:
I stopped drinking coffee when it started giving me heartburn and acid reflux.  And theoretically I gave up chocolate, cookies, and any combination thereof.  I am also allergic to nuts.  And I'm cheap.  Like cheap date, and cheep of wallet.  

The coffee at this place makes Lou moist in his wiggly place.  Does he have more than one wiggly place?  Does his equipment get moist in the rain?  Does Lou think about moisting his wiggly place?  I bet he does.  Lou will rip my head off, run across the street in the rain and order an espresso from this place.  I think one time he made me take a sip of his ice coffee to which I made an angry squinty face like a puckered anus and said "delicious."

Today I bought a chocolate chip cookie.  It was from some company called "goody"?  It was an expensive cookie.  Sure it was 70% chocolate chunks.  But it was $2.75.  That's more than specialties.  I spend too much money on chocolate chip cookies.  Tomorrow I'm going to get more chocolate chip cookies.  But maybe not from here because as a cheap student who is about to become gainfully unemployed, I am not made of money.
author: Christina C.

description:
Holy secret coffee shop!

Awesome Blue Bottle-roasted single cup drip coffee and fantastic espresso drinks, made fresh for you in an alley by friendly, cool baristas. Skip Starbucks and come here for real coffee at only a small price premium. It's completely displaced chain coffee in my weekday caffeination routine.

It's not the fastest -- expect to wait a couple minutes, longer if there's a line -- but it is seriously, seriously worth it.
author: Anthony R.

description: SOLID!!! Try the secret menu "Special Xtra" which is their take on a Gibralter (sorry, for there only ... no to-go's). This place is one of the few reasons I wish I still worked at my previous employer. A special xtra bonus is that you can watch the progress on the trans bay construction.
author: Matthew J M.

description: Great find! They made me an iced decaf americano on the spot, not even an item on their menu. My friend got the chocolate chip cookie with kettle corn...couldn't stop raving about it. This spot just may become my new go-to for afternoon strolls...
author: Erin W.

description:
I was feeling the mid-day slump so my team and I ventured over here to try this place. It is a pop-up coffee shop that uses the doorway of a club. We actually thought this was a Blue Bottle, but when we came here, we realized that it is actually a different coffee-shop that just serves Blue Bottle coffee (which is still good enough for me)

What I got: 
Macau Iced Coffee - First time I got this, I would say this is a cup of milk, with a side of espresso/coffee. They probably filled the cup with 80% milk, 1 shot of espresso and a little sweetener (just sweet enough for my liking). Personally, I didn't expect there to be so much milk and I usually like my coffee to have a more.. um ..coffee taste, so it was okay - 3 stars.

Handy Tip: 
This place does not accept credit cards (cash only), so come prepared. Also I noted per their menu that their New Orleans Iced Coffee is actually served unsweetened which I believe is different compared to Blue Bottle.
author: Melissa L.

description:
Full disclosure: this place is owned by one of my coworker's cousins, and another one of her cousins works there and some other relatives are involved somehow. I was going to forward this review to her but she said she's already sick of hearing about it at family reunions so I won't bother.

from 7:30 AM to 4:00 in the afternoon, the smoking patio at Harlot is opened up and turned into a semi-outdoor coffee bar. They use blue bottle coffee, and serve individually brewed cups and fancy lattes with little ripple designs in the foam. It's kind of expensive and takes a few minutes, but that's to be expected.

The staff is friendly, though they tend to squint at you because in the mornings the sun shines right in their eyes from behind you, so you and the other customers probably just look like silohuettes to them. Even if you never tipped them, they probably wouldn't be able to recognize you as the guy who never tips. You should always tip them though.
author: matthew r.

description:
Isn't "Special Xtra" what you asked for after a back rub at Nikki Rose's Massage Parlor? Oh wait, that's a "knock knock", right Ruggy?

A visit here feels almost just as shady though. Take an unwitting work buddy behind the Transbay terminal past the shopping carts full of peoples' lives and duck into the back alley behind Harlot. Their breath will come easier after they see all the suit-clad folks standing around sipping merrily on brewed beverages procured from a little alcove with a gleaming espresso machine. (Do they not realize there's a perfectly nice, modern courtyard around the corner with odd Easter Island-looking heads, or a rooftop greenishspace just a quick ways to the right?)

Prepare for the glory of Blue Bottle's caffeine to rain on you. A quick jolt can be had in many ways: all the things ending in "ay" and "oh" sounds, drip coffee, and my personal favorite, the New Orleans iced coffee with chicory. (Which btw, is the root of an endive. Weird!)

Who needs 5-hour Energy, anyway?
author: Ligaya T.

description:
Blue bottle coffee without the blue bottle line or the blue bottle hauteur. My only gripe is that there's no place to sit down and enjoy a cup of coffee -- the nearby public open space is one of San Francisco's most powerful wind tunnels. None of the nearby alley, the road with a constant stream of BMWs, or the abandoned shopping cart next to the Transbay terminal are any better.

Still gets 5 stars because the other coffee in SOMA is terrible in comparison.
author: Daniel C.

description:
I'm just writing this review so I can bask in the glow of the little badge that says I have ~150 check-ins here. Obviously I love this place.

Tips:

Familiarize yourself with the state of Transbay Terminal deconstruction before visiting in case routes are blocked.

The average skill of the female baristas is greater than the average skill of the male baristas, but the average skill of all baristas is still very very high. It took me about 3 months before I could even notice a difference between anyone.

Someone try a peanut butter cookie and review it. They look fantastic.
author: Connor Skye R.

description: Tucked away next to the Transbay terminal is this gem. No better place to get a shot of espresso than here.
author: Vince H.

description:
I asked for a Red Eye... the barista looks me square in the eye and says "No.  We won't make those."  Not "sorry," just "no."

I'm taken aback.  "You won't put a shot of espresso in a cup of coffee?"

"No.  It compromises the flavor of both the espresso and the coffee."

"But I order them here all the time."

"WHO MAKES THEM FOR YOU?  WHAT ARE THEIR NAMES???"

Sheesh. 

First of all, have you ever tasted your Red Eyes?  Cause they're damn good.  

Second, I worked at an even more pretentious coffee shop and we never would have rejected a customer request like that... if someone wanted coffee grounds on toast, we would have served them.  Or at least treated them with some small measure of respect.

Next time, as someone in line behind me suggested, I'm ordering an espresso and a cup of coffee, then pouring them together right in that dude's face.  The place is right by my work and I need my late afternoon coffee break, but who wants to deal with service like that?
author: Ian M.

description:
skip the line at peet's and your stale starbucks espresso
for this gem serving up some blue bottle drip. 
and tasty caffee lattes
just make sure to bring cash$$ yo atm will not be respected 

thanks special Xtra. my new favorite
author: Summer K.

description: Almost two years strong. These awesome people make some amazing coffee. drips to order and a simple menu. Want a tall Carmel whatever? too bad. Go somewhere else. good people. good coffee. Actually, I would argue they are better than the roaster's cafe in JL Square.
author: Giancarlo G.

description: The Dish: They sell Blue Bottle coffee here. Definitely a good place to go when the ferry building's Blue Bottle Stand has a line curving throughout the building. The only bad thing is that it's kind of in a back alley and there's really nothing around except for construction. But honestly, no lines + blue bottle coffee is enough to bring me back.
author: Gina T.

description:
I returned here for one of their lovely lattes on this fine afternoon in the City.  I used to frequent here when I spent many days in the building that also houses this cool coffee spot but it had been some time since I switched jobs across town. (They serve up Blue Bottle for those readers new to this spot).

Same killer latte, same great crew.  Don't go changin'! ;-)
author: John K.

description:
Blue Bottle Coffee is the best in the Bay Area. It is very exciting to have Special Xtra move in to SOMA. This place is located in what is usually the smokers lounge of Harlot nightclub behind Salt House Restaurant and is owned by the same folks that operate Cento. The staff is friendly and into their coffee. Only downside is a drip here is $2.50 versus $2 at the Hayes Valley kiosk, but you have to pay to play in the financial district. 

P.S: I wrote this review in 3 seconds because I am so alive with Blue Bottle coffee energy. 

YEAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAHHHHHHHHHHHHHHH... COFFEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEE!!!!..............
author: Sean K.

description: Tasty, tasty Blue Bottle coffee, cute spot, and a view of the ever evolving site of the new Transit Terminal.
author: Jenni S.

description:
Thank you THANK YOU for saving me from the horrible coffee in the SOMA area between 2nd and 1st. 

For YEARS I've been going to the Starbucks next to 2nd and Folsom and suffering from the poor coffee drinks made there. (I'm a creature of habit. What can I say.)

LUCKILY I found Special Xtra on the hunt for coffee that is better than the Starbucks closer to work.  I had the Cafe au lait and a kettle corn chocolate chip cookie. YUM!! 

Will definitely head back here again.

Just to follow all the bulldozers to find Special Xtra and don't forget the ear plugs.
author: She R. A.

description:
I go to school just up from the alley that this place is located.  It's a nice respite from the drudgery and commonplaceness of the bucks and the peets.

They make my americanos delicious, usually are playing good tunes, and are pretty cool peeps.

Yes, you  may have to walk past the wall that has shit on it from a bum who couldn't wait.  Yes, sometimes it feels like you're walking through skid row.  But for a delicious cup I'd walk through...well...I guess that's the extent I'm willing to go for coffee.
author: Pouria Y.

description:
I've worked very close to this place for well over a year and the coffee is great, but the customer service is terrible. Today I stood in line behind 4 other people waiting for coffee. The lady went ahead and took down the espresso machine before asking me if I had ordered anything. She then informed me that she had already "cleaned it out" and couldn't make any more coffee.

This will be the last time I go to this overpriced yuppy hole.
author: Nick K.

description: Arguably the finest and closest espresso to my work building. It's tucked away in a nondescript alleyway, but all the cool kids know where it's at, so there's often a crowd. The baristas are friendly and know how to pull a shot (the Blue Bottle espresso tastes uniquely darker and richer than what's served at its eponymous cafes spattered throughout the city). Cash only and well worth the minimal wait.
author: Alyssa W.

description:
Love the smooth coffee.  

Love the staff.

The crowd is always interesting and changing.  I wish I could just stand there all day.
author: Edward A.

description: Very good coffee and espresso, usually without a long line. Being in an alley across from what is currently the Transbay Terminal construction site makes it feel like a special secret.
author: William C.

description:
This place will help motivate me to "do the right thing" come July when the Bay Bridge rises to an unthinkable $6- I really need to take the bus to work instead of driving and voila- Special Xtra could be my reward..

Macau iced coffee= Vietnamesesque caffeinated delight and the made to order drip is the real deal
author: Sara K.

description:
Came here a few times with the crew from work. It's chill spot that is open till 4 so we can get a out late afternoon caffeine fix in. No real wait no scene other than just get your coffee and go. Simple as that. They serve blue bottle coffee and sometimes I see some juice/ice tea drinks served too when it's hot. However when it is that hot I just go for the Macau iced coffee (guilty pleasure). However usually I just go with the drip. The baristas are chill and well the atmosphere is ... an alley way. But there is park right around the corner to sit at. I have been warned that it is not wise to sit on the concrete wall there.


PS. Seems to be cash only.
author: Greg G.

description:
The way I see it, if you're going to walk down a sketchy alley and be faced with someone less fortunate than you taking a piss FACING IN YOUR DIRECTION (at least the peeps down in the mission turn the other way), you mind as well have a special blend Blue Bottle (good, not my favorite) latte in your hand.

The whole experience was, shall I say, Xtra Special.
author: Jason B.

description:
Now I know how Cappuccino is supposed to taste.  I also ordered the waffle and it was the best waffle I have ever eaten (I consider myself an unofficial waffle connoisseur ;-)).
I think I finally understand why San Franciscans are so snobby about their coffee.
author: Kattya B.

description:
Skilled baristas that use bluebottle coffee. Result? Consistently great coffee.

This place was a near daily haunt for me when I worked nearby, definitely the best coffee in the neighborhood.

If you want a seat to chill out and drink your coffee, check out the courtyard between Minna and Mission a couple hundred feet west.
author: Marc S.

description: way better than peets, tullys, or sb. and underneith my office. sweet.
author: Dylan ..

description:
YES! A blue bottle behind my office! This just made work that much better :)

Wedged between Harlot's front door and a few sketchy parking lots, this beacon of happiness almost made me scream with joy out loud this morning.

Thank you Blue Bottle Empire for your continuous commitment to spreading your caffeinated joy to San Francisco
author: Gabrielle J.

description:
** In protest of the Dolores Park cart debacle, I am giving 5 stars to all the Blue Bottle kiosks where I get coffee.  Three Africans all the way!  Sorry you had to deal with the haters Blue Bottle. **


I'm not a regular here, but I might be if my office didn't have free coffee in the a.m.  Baristas are friendly and the line's not too long.
author: Tullia F.

description:
I was desperate for some coffee before beginning my Bar studies.  WOW, i thought to myself, a coffee kiosk between my parking garage and school.  I could just taste the Mocha I was about to order....my mouth was salivating . . .  

Service was very friendly .. .  but as soon as I took a sip of my mocha, well, it tasted anything but a mocha.  It wasn't sweet at all.  I guess they use regular, plain ol' cocoa powder (that is unsweetened) instead of the sweet stuff that makes a mocha, well, sweet.  I was very disappointed and had to toss my coffee and head over to one of the other over-priced coffee establishments to get my sugar/caffeine fix.
author: Karen B.

description:
Yay, I'm a fan because there are no lines, it's on my way work, and conveniently behind an alley off the beaten path that most people may not even notice.

I'm not a big coffee fan, but I have appreciated the drip coffee and the NOLA iced coffee. The regular drip coffee was bitter at first, but becomes smooth after a few sips. I'm still deciding whether I like the NOLA iced coffee--a good indicator that it's not the greatest in the world.

Tips:

-They serve the NOLA iced coffee in the to go cups that hot beverages are served in. This caused the cup to smear the "Special Xtra" blue ink stamp on my hand from the condensation.
-Make sure your lid is securely fastened when you put it on.
author: Brandi G.

description:
This is a little hole in the wall you would never find unless someone brings you there or points it out to you. They make their coffee with Blue Bottle coffees, which is a local bay area favorite. 

I love their espresso! Their lattes are soooo smooth and tasty, and are of course double shots. 

Their drip coffee is actually drip coffee - they put your cup under a filter and pour hot water over the coffee. You get a truly fresh coffee, and again, it's super smooth. 

If you're into Peets coffee or other super strong coffees, you probably wouldn't like the coffee here. It's not strong or harsh at all, and they don't aim to be that way. 

The biggest draw back to this place is that fact that's it's so small. Even when the line is only 5-6 people, you're still set back about 10 minutes to get your caffeine. But that's because it's not a commercial coffee place and they do take time with each cup to make it a certain way, and that's what I think makes it so yummy!

If you're a coffee fan, do yourself a favor and check this place out!
author: Erik B.

description:
Unabashed peeing, yes, that might happen on your way from the Transbay Terminal to Special Xtra, but you may also see the old bow-legged dude with the 20-pound mohair cat (leashed) chillaxin on his shoulder. More than redemption.
Meanwhile, nevermind the yeowwch price, it's 7:30 in the morning and the Special Xtra people are ready to make a consistently perfect cup of blue bottle drip coffee. Thank jeebus. They treat a highly diverse public with courtesy and efficiency, and their occupation of that tiny niche next to the mysterious harlot club seems physically implausible. I always turn around when I get halfway down the block, two greedy gulps into the brew, truly expecting Special Xtra to have returned to the Special Xtra dimension. So far, happily, I mean it and I think you know why, I've always been wrong.
author: suki o.

description:
Love it, love it, love it.

Great coffee and lattes, along with friendly and very attractive workers.   What's not to love?
author: Lynn S.

description: How am I getting Blue Bottle coffee out of Harlot?!?  Only wish Blue Bottle was still a five star coffee to be fair to Special Xtra, but its still an exceptinal alternative to the twenty something deep line at the Ferry Building.  Its slightly reminiscent to the Hayes Valley Blue Bottle window, but a hundred times less cooler and 99 times less coller than Vega.  Maybe they can do something realted to the construction???
author: Aaron I.

description: I take off one star for not accepting credit cards...however their blue bottle coffee is great!
author: Ojas V.

description:
Ignore the walk down a pretty sketch alley, this place is worth the stop if you need some good coffee. Only real downside is that it's cash only.  

They serve Blue Bottle Coffee and I've learned from coming here that my initial negative assessment of Blue Bottle was way off. I'm kind of addicted now and need to have some in my system around 3 pm every work day.  

The people there are super nice and they are great with faces.  Come here enough and you don't even have to order because they know exactly what you want. 

Also, their chocolate chip cookies are amazing.  Seriously, it's mostly chocolate.  I don't even know how they can bake a cookie with that much chocolate in it.
author: Alea G.

description: Good cup of coffee.   They need more help as the line gets long...  I am not a latte drinker but I was tempted as it looked good.
author: Myoung K.

description:
One of the growing number of Blue Bottle Coffee authorized resellers (as I like to call places selling Blue Bottle's coffees), Special Xtra is a good addition to the Financial District because it brings high quality coffee to an area dominated by Starbucks, Peets, and those slowly-burning-coffee-in-an-urn sort of places.

Much like the actual Blue Bottle cafés, the coffee here is either individually dripped or made into an espresso or espresso-based drink.  I think the espressos are only "for here," which really isn't a problem since you're supposed to finish the damn thing in like 1 or 2 sips.
author: Suo L.

description:
I've been a consistent customer of Special Extra for several months now.  Unfortunately it did not take much time for them to undo my high praises and recommendations.

I will be honest and rate their coffee with 4 stars, but their service barely deserves one star, which is something Pete's will get right most of the time.

Today I brought a small crowd from my company (normally composed of Pete/Starbucks fans) to Special Extra.  I have been doing this for a while now.  Special Extra was somewhat busy (I've seen them much busier) and delivered a lukewarm latte.  I asked the barista if they could make it hotter, to which she replied that she could add some hot water.  At this point, Pete's would have offered to re-make it, which is the standard I was hoping they would achieve, but did not.  I asked her politely if she could re-make it, and to my surprise, she snapped and responded with a very, very irritated look.  She and the other baristo behind the counter had a quiet conversation, and then she exclaimed, "well you're just gonna have to wait since we're busy."  I understand what food service can be like especially when its busy, but I was shocked by her reaction, and all of my pro Special Extra enthusiasm has been completely wiped away.

I hope the owner of manager of Special Extra sees this, as I hope his/her goal is to create fans and not be rude to once loyal customers.

Our group has decided we will go to Pete's next time, where the coffee may not be as good, but we would be treated with respect, which to me, is more important.
author: Tai K.

description:
Compared to the real Blue Bottle cafes at the Mint and at the Ferry Building, this reseller just doesn't compare. The coffee is not as smooth as it should be, which for me, is the point of Blue Bottle coffee. It is VERY convenient to my office though and so it gets points there. They also sell bags of beans.

There's usually a short line that goes by quickly.

Do not get the hot chocolate. It was so bad I had to throw it away.
author: Grace Y.

description: I love this place.  Fantastic coffee and it's down a nice little side street, somehow making it feel secluded from all the soma craziness.  Try the new orleans coffee if you'd like to experience one of the most extreme caffeine highs possible.
author: Yan L.

description: I showed up at 4:03 and they were rude and said "we're closed, sorry" as they were making coffee in front of me (and people had just ordered).  TERRIBLE customer service.
author: Pamela L.

description:
w00t! Made my day when I saw this stand walking back from lunch. 

$2.50 for drip
$3.50 for latte

A little pricey but totally worth it.
author: Phong D.

description: Since I'm a loyal Philz fan and there isn't one near my work, I decided to try this small stand.  While the coffee may be great as others mention, I wouldn't know because the bartistas were so rude that they wouldn't make the drink I asked for.  Now I'm not some high-maintenance customer believe me--I usually get a regular coffee and add cream and sugar. All I wanted was a coffee with chocolate in it!  They were so snobby and full of themselves about their "simple menu" that they actually called what I wanted "gross".  The only gross thing about it was the way that I was treated as a customer. Highly NOT recommended. And the coffee isn't even that good.
author: Lisa E.

description: Such a good start to my day thought about giving it a 4 to keep the line down bit good crew working there thus want them to succeed.  After going here for a couple of years I can't bear to stop at peet's or sbux.  Stop by and give it a try, you won't be disappointed.  The food looks great and watching people bite into the cheese sandwich is real food porn.
author: mike s.

description: They can't customzie my drink like other places...I know it's supposed to be great coffee but if I am going to be paying $4 for a small mocha I would hope it get it the way I want it.
author: Panda G.

description: Points for having a sawhorse sign on the corner to remind me they're in the alley. Great coffee!
author: Emily M.

description: There aren't many places in San Francisco where one can obtain their Blue Bottle fix whilst engaging in a lengthy discourse about the merits of Aliens v. Alien 3.  This, however, is one such place.  Special indeed.
author: Michael D.

description: Nestled in a hole around the corner from my office, Special Xtra has really awesome coffee, glad I found this gem on Yelp, because I think I would have overlooked it otherwise!
author: Michael O.

description: Really glad to see a place that sells blue bottle coffee by my office. Now i don't have to bike down to mint, or settle for a watery burnt cup of coffee! (you can get a decent cup near by, but compared to this it sucks) It's not technically owned by BB, but they sell all the same stuff and their staff is trained by BB. It's a bit pricey for a cup of drip ($2.50). But is totally worth it to a one cup a day drinker like me. If you've never tried blue bottle its worth checking out for sure. If you don't like it then you have bad taste. haha!
author: Tim R.

description: Score!  Like the original Blue Bottle kiosk only transplanted in FiDi.  With more homeless people.  And shopping carts.  And urine.  I must have gone on a good day but the construction wasn't so bad - I actually like the industrial feel it gives the place, it felt like I was back home in Chicago.  I love the takeaway kiosk trend that's hit SF and this place is no exception and since the coffee is Blue Bottle, it's great as always.  I must have had bad luck with my soy latte, the milk was burnt, otherwise great find, highly recommend it!
author: Rosers M.

description: My cousin, Cin introduced me to this secret Blue Bottle coffee spot.  It was love at first sip. I seriously cannot get over having the iced Macau-- it's truly that awesome!  Trust.
author: Mae R.

description: Blue Bottle coffee to me is crack.  When I drink other coffee, I sigh in disappointment, and long to go back to BB.  Special Xtra is awesome!  It's located at the Harlot Nighclub patio, hidden on Minna Alley in downtown SF.  The great part about this coffee spot is the staff...great job!
author: Dennise A.

description: I love, love, love Blue Bottle Coffee!!!!!!!!! This little pit stop here has the great coffee without the pretension. Awesome!!!!
author: Martha H.

description: Great lattes, just like you would expect from blue bottle.
author: Robert T.

description: Straight to the point: it's the ONLY place to get a decent coffee downtown
author: Gabriel N.

description: BEST S*** ever.  Hands down, the best coffee I have ever enjoyed.  It is now a daily routine to go pick up my macau soy iced coffee at this place.
author: Kerry Z.

description: Awesome drip coffee. If you want a venti double-twist skim cafe macchiato, then go somewhere else. But this place has actual, honest-to-goodness coffee that doesn't taste like motor oil when you drink it black. Awesome.
author: James B.

description: Hmm...they don't seem to be making their cappuccinos as well these days. They seem to just be a smaller version of their latte. Too heavy. So, I've switched to drinking their Lattes, which are delicious.
author: Cearull H.

description:
Great place to grab a coffee break while downtown.  A bit off the beaten path, but worth the minor detour.

New Orleans iced coffee is my first choice.
author: Kent S.

description: So I dropped by to see Brian at Special Xtra SOMA this week, and had amazing Blue Bottle coffee.  This place rocks.  Same great brew (well, drip) as at the Ferry Building, less the line.  Both Brian and Clay provide exceptional, fun service.
author: Eric S.

description: hidden gem that has great coffee but even better baristas.  pretty special place to come get a superb cup of coffee/latte/"the macao" - all blue bottle beans too.  i am here every day to get my dose of caffeine but mostly, a dose of smiles.
author: Sonia C.

description: Great coffee, friendly people, and right behind my office! What more could I ask for?
author: Greyson M.

description: It was a very pleasant surprise to see Blue Bottle coffee available in this neck of the woods. Latte made perfectly, friendly staff - brings back the memories of short lines at Linden Lane & guerrilla style coffee carts at the Ferry building.
author: John W.

description: if you know what's up, you can charm the usual morning barista into making you a "john."  and lest i get in trouble, that's all i'm going to say about that.
author: Stephanie L.

description: it's a cute little coffee kiosk in an alley and the maccau iced coffee is what will bring me back here.
author: Catherine G.

description: I like Cento, Vega, and Xtra cuz I can my blue bottle with much less wait.  But this location is not as good as the other two..
author: A P.

description: Coffee is overpriced and not the best I've had, although it's good. But the nasty staff people (not the location) are the reason for this review. Two times in a row we have had really super unpleasant experiences with the counter help. Here's a tip (besides the one which I stupidily left you): Don't yell at your customers in a condescending manner, especially after one of them has (stupidly) tipped you. I wish I would have given that dollar to a homeless person instead of you.
author: Isabel P.

description: A real shame as I was so excited about having that so close to work... However, they made a really gross curdled soya cappucino - but the worst part is that I guess they have no idea how to handle customers when given constructive feedback. Here is what happened - I went back the next day to very nicely explain to the guy what had happened with the drink I bought there (noticed the issue after a few sips as I could see and taste the funny soya and this was the second time for the same issue and I didn't want to go back since I had treated a colleague for a cup of coffee and we were in our meeting already). I was very nice and just told him the story and his attitude was pretty surprising. He basically nodded and made it pretty clear he didn't care at all, his colleague didn't pipe up either, and he did not even offer to make me a new coffee, which is what any other place would do, I am sure (I stood there in my designer suit and accessories so he knew I wasn't trying to scam a coffee or something). Do not go there - go to Peet's or something which is 2 mins from there...
author: E H.

description: So happy to have a Blue Bottle closer to the office.  Best coffee downtown PERIOD.  They sell beans too, so I don't have to make the trek to the ferry building.  Awesome staff.
author: Paul J.

description: cento is my local, but special xtra is keeping the faith
author: Wangston P.
